unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Constructing a $2$ Proportion $z$-Interval: High School Break Up
question_text:
Independent random samples of $50$ boys and $50$ girls in a school were asked if they are depressed for more than a week after they got broken up with by their significant other. Of the $50$ boys, $26$ said yes, and of the $50$ girls, $35$ said yes.
Which of the following is a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the proportion of boys compared to the proportion of girls who are depressed for more than a week after they have been broken with by their significant other in this school?
solution:
This is a $2$ proportion $z$-interval. The formula for the $2$ proportion $z$-interval is:

$${ (\hat { p } }_{ 1 }-{ \hat { p } }_{ 2 })\pm { z }^{ * }\sqrt { \dfrac { ({ \hat { p } }_{ 1 })(1-{ \hat { p } }_{ 1 }) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\dfrac { { \hat { (p } }_{ 2 })({ 1-\hat { p } }_{ 2 }) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } }$$

Note that the standard deviation for the difference of two proportions is given on the AP formula sheet.

We can use process of elimination to solve this. To find the critical value ($z^*$) for $95\%$, look at table B ($t$-distribution of critical values) and look directly above $95\%$.

An alternative approach to solving this: if you do not know the formula, run the $2$ proportion $z$-interval on your calculator and get the interval. Then, do the calculations out for all the choices and see which one matches your interval you received on the calculator.

Explanation of Distractors

We can see that for $95\%$, the critical value is $1.96$ on the t-distribution. This value comes from the normal distribution. Therefore, we can eliminate Choices 'A' and 'C'.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because the interval was pooled. We pool in $2$ proportion $z$-tests, but not in $2$ proportion $z$-intervals.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because the standard error (the content in the square root) component is wrong.
